subtitle: Learning by clicking

---

<a href="https://raw.githubusercontent.com/panel-demos/glaciers/master/assets/dashboard.png">
<img src="https://raw.githubusercontent.com/panel-demos/glaciers/master/assets/dashboard.png"
alt="Image missing" width="100%" /></a>

As you may know, we recently developed an interactive visualization
during a [hackathon](https://oggm.org/2018/06/11/opendatahack2018/) in June.

The app was based on [Dash by Plotly](https://plot.ly/products/dash/) and at
that time I was astonished how quickly I was able to create an interactive app
from scratch, without any knowledge of either Plotly or Dash.

More recently, I got curious about impressive new tools developed by the
[PyViz](http://pyviz.org/) team, and I started a
[Twitter discussion](https://twitter.com/OGGM_org/status/1051573292463808513)
which ended **much** further than I would have expected!

## The application

The PyViz members [Philipp Rudiger](https://github.com/philippjfr) and
[James Bednar](https://github.com/jbednar) took the challenge and made
a new PyViz app to replace the Dash one in no time.

The app can be launched directly on MyBinder by clicking on the following link:
 <a href="https://mybinder.org/v2/gh/panel-demos/glaciers/master?urlpath=/proxy/5006/app">
<img style="float: left;" src="https://img.shields.io/badge/launch-binder%20app-579ACA.svg?logo=data:image/png;base64,">
</a>

The code is hosted on [github](https://github.com/panel-demos/glaciers).

## About the app

Visit this [dedicated page](http://edu.oggm.org/en/latest/explorer.html) to learn how to use the app and links to the data sources.

## Datashader

For reference, [here](https://dash.klima.uni-bremen.de/apps/explore) is the
equivalent application I wrote in Dash back in June. I won't start a  
debate about the difference between Dash and PyViz here (for a summmary, refer to
the [official Panel FAQ](https://panel.pyviz.org/FAQ.html)). Furthermore, the
two apps are not equivalent, and my Dash and
CSS knowledge are too poor to make a fair comparison out of it.

However, the biggest difference between the old app and the new PyViz one is that
the old one uses a reduced version of the data. Indeed, to make the app run
smoothly, we
had to bin the data into longitude/latitude ranges to reduce the total number
of points to visualize. The PyViz app can rely on [DataShader](http://datashader.org/)
to reduce the data *on the go*, i.e. display the 200'000+ glacier points interactively
without any latency. This is simply awesome, and opens many new opportunities
for global visualizations based on OGGM.
